title: Mugs
text:
A good mug is tactile. I care about how it feels in my hands. I need to be able to cradle it with two hands, but also to hold it in one hand with fingers through the handle.
The handle feel is important, too! I’ve been inspired by the great Lane May (child extrordinaire) to make wide flat slab handles instead of pulled/coil handles. I like the way they feel.
These mugs are “stoneware”, which means they’re from a dense clay fired at high temperatures. Stoneware is super strong, chip resistant, and good for everyday use - microwaves, ovens, dishwashers…if you drop one of these mugs it might hurt your toe but probably won’t hurt the mug.
Each mug is handmade and one-of-a-kind. Lately I’ve been thinking about mugs as canvases. Functional little paintings.

title: Pod of Whales
text:
These whale were in my mind for a long time.


I used to work in an office space with a super high ceiling, and I had this image of the ocean and the different biological niches. You know, the sunlight zone, the twilight zone… we were the bottom dwellers in this tall tall space and there could be different biological niches above us and we’d just be oblivious to it.




 


 



In real life, it can feel like your entire biological niche changes when you change your social circle. Like…changing your job or go through a breakup…like you live in the same town but never see all the people you used to see every day. Or you start a new hobby or make a new friend and that gives you a whole new social world. All of these lives are going on around us and it doesn’t take much to make the world feel totally different.










The feeling of the different whales relating to one another— they’re playing, they’re dancing, they’re in their bodies and joyful. Movement. A sense of movement and connectedness. What must it feel like to dive like that? To be that powerful of a swimmer?

title: Tall Drink of Water Mug
text:
One of “my” crows is tall! I think. They’re very hard to tell apart.
Why is this exciting? Because I’m starting to get to know them as individuals.
  
I spend a lot of time thinking about the little leg feathers they have. Like little trousers, little jodpurs, little feather leggings they pull on in the morning.

Look at this crow. This is a tall crow. I swear to god.

title: Sketchy Crows
text:
Okay, so this is important to me because it’s more fluid, more like a sketch, more kinda seeing what happens. Less like a plan with very clear clean outlines, less like a cartoon, less controlled. I like stuff that has a weird messy energy.
Carving clay feels amazing. Sometimes I crave it (not making that up). I loved the chaos of carving those horizontal stripes. Chaos gremlin release!
This crow from behind is my favorite. Mysterious. 
Then she turns and make awkward eye contact. Whut? 
This is the least successful carving although the one I love the most from the reference sketch. I can’t get that head tilt right yet! 
This is the reference sketch I made to work from. 
And here’s an example of the reference pictures I’m taking of MY CROWS lately because they trust me and come when I whistle and come very close to me. Squeeeeeeeeeeee.

title: Mark Making Mug
text:
I got up in the middle of the night with this strong urge to carve. Not really about a final image, but a feeling of what my hands wanted to do. So I got up and carved this. In art school people talked about “being interested in mark making*” and I always thought that was pretentious. But there’s something soothing about making the same motion over and over - repetitive hand movements. Why knitting, coloring, all kinds of things are soothing. I find working with clay therapeutic, and it was soothing to do this just focused on the feeling, not with an image of how I wanted it to turn out.
Glaze notes: So far it’s saffron yellow and flame Speedball underglaze. After bisque, I want to fill in the carving spots with black or brown underglaze, then glaze the whole thing maybe with saffron glaze?
*Note: the only other time I heard this was daycare teachers talking about babies making art - just being interested in what it’s like to make a mark.

title: Singing Whale
text: Sigh. I really loved this whale, but I screwed up the glazing. So we’ll just say that I learned a lot. Maybe someday I’ll try to reglaze and fire.

title: Holy Whale
text:
Male humpbacks sing for hours, spiraling slowly as their voices carry for miles. This sculpture holds that moment — peaceful, embodied, part of the great chorus.




































Hand sculpted in stoneware for lasting durability, indoors or out. Dimensions: 16” × 8” × 4” (41 × 20 × 10 cm). Two mounting holes allow for easy hanging with nails, screws, or wire.
Stoneware goes through two firings. Here it is after sculpting, before the first fire — and a glimpse of the hollowing process that makes large pieces possible.

This summer I watched a juvenile crow beg for food while she was standing on food. The begging went on for days. Man, oh man, it really made me empathize with the parents. And crows do it every year! This a set of four small plates is an ode to parental patience and how hard it is to raise kids. :) They’re little plates - perfect for dunking chicken nuggets in ketchup or holding your rings.

title: About
text:
I have a PhD in Neuroscience from the University of Oregon and work as a Workflow Coach for Posit Software.
I tend to find the social lives of non-human animals interesting - thus crows and whales as subject matter.
